attributes.description: The eldest son of King Daśaratha, known for his truth and virtue, who is departing for fourteen years of forest exile.
The wife of Ráma and daughter of King Janak; she insists on sharing her husband's exile and wears bark garments before being given royal robes by the King.
The King of Ayodhyá and father of Ráma; he is overcome with grief and physical collapse due to the forced banishment of his son.
The queen whose boons forced Ráma's exile; she is denounced by the King and the people for her cruelty.
The loyal brother of Ráma who accompanies him into exile to serve and protect the royal couple.
The mother of Ráma and chief queen; she is left in a state of 'whelming woe' at her son's departure.
The mother of LakshmaG; she encourages her son to serve Ráma as he would his own father.
The King's charioteer and counselor who drives the trio to the forest boundary.
The capital city of the Ikshváku line, described as desolate and filled with lamentation during Ráma's departure.
The son of Kaikeyí; the King predicts he will refuse to rule the kingdom obtained through his mother's guile.
Another name for Indra, the King of Gods, used as a peer-comparison for King Daśaratha.
The God of Death and ruler of the nether realm.
The momentous exit of Ráma, Sítá, and LakshmaG from Ayodhyá, marked by cosmic omens and city-wide mourning.

attributes.context: Father and son; Daśaratha's love for Ráma is his primary life force.
Wife and husband; Sítá is described as Ráma's 'self and soul'.
Brother and devoted servant; LakshmaG follows Ráma by choice.
Wife; she is repudiated by the King for her 'selfish heart'.
The charioteer who drives the chariot out of the city.
The city he is leaving to go into the wild woods.
Mother-in-law; she counsels Sítá on the duties of a faithful wife.
